questions.text: Nucleus pulposus is derived from? (AIIMS 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Mark b

 

Explanation:

 

  • The notochord is a rod-like structure that forms during embryonic development and serves as the foundation for the future vertebral column.
  • The nucleus pulposus, the central gel-like core of the intervertebral disc, is derived from the notochord. The notochord initially provides structural support to the developing embryo and later contributes to the formation of the intervertebral discs.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mark d. Ectoderm:

 

  • The ectoderm is another primary germ layer of the developing embryo and gives rise to structures such as the nervous system, skin, and epidermal tissues.
  • The ectoderm does not contribute to the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Option C. Mark a. Intraembryonic Mesoderm:

 

  • The intraembryonic mesoderm is a layer of embryonic tissue that gives rise to various structures in the developing embryo, including muscles, bones, and connective tissues.
  • While mesoderm does play a role in the development of the vertebral column and its associated structures, the nucleus pulposus specifically derives from the notochord.

 

Option D. Mark c. Endoderm:

 

  • The endoderm is one of the three primary germ layers of the developing embryo and gives rise to the epithelial linings of various organs, including the gastrointestinal tract, respiratory tract, and other internal organs.
  • The endoderm is not directly involved in the formation of the nucleus pulposus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Gastrulation (Embryonic development of the germ layers):

 

  • Gastrulation is the early embryological process by which an embryo changes from a one-dimensional layer of epithelial cells (blastula) to a multilayered structure known as a gastrula.
  • The notochord is a rod-like embryological structure that is derived during gastrulation and plays an important role in vertebrate development.
  • The nucleus pulposus is the gelatinous centre of the intervertebral disc formed by the expansion of the notochord (by its remnants). As a result, it is derived from the notochord.

questions.text: What is the origin of the fibers marked by the arrow? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above image is the cross-section of the human brain in which the marked arrow indicates the fornix.
  • Fornix belongs to projectional fibers which are the type of white matter fibers. Fornix forms the efferent fibers of the hippocampus and connects it with the mammillary body. Hence the origin of fibers is hippocampus
  • The fornix is a white matter bundle located in the medial aspect of the cerebral hemispheres which arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mamillary body of the hypothalamus.
  • It connects various nodes of a limbic circuitry and is believed to play a key role in cognition and episodic memory recall.
  • Fornix is an example of association fiber and is supplied by the anterior cerebral artery.
  • The hippocampus is a seahorse-shaped structure located within the temporal lobes of the brain. The fornix originates from the hippocampus. Specifically, it receives input from the hippocampus and sends axons that project back to the hippocampus. This loop of connections is involved in memory formation and retrieval.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Habenular: The habenular nuclei are small structures located near the thalamus and are involved in various functions, including the regulation of the pineal gland's activity. The fornix is not directly associated with the habenular nuclei. Instead, it primarily connects the hippocampus to other structures in the limbic system.

 

Option C. Mammillary Body: The mammillary bodies are a pair of small, round structures located on the undersurface of the brain. The fornix connects the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies. This connection is an essential component of the Papez circuit, a neural circuit involved in memory and emotion.

 

Option D. Amygdala: The amygdala is an almond-shaped structure located deep within the temporal lobes and plays a key role in processing emotions, particularly fear and emotional memory. While the amygdala is part of the limbic system, it is not directly connected to the fornix. Instead, the amygdala communicates with other limbic structures through various neural pathways.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Among the following, what is the function of the green muscles marked? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Depression

 

Explanation:

 

The muscle marked in green is the lateral pterygoid muscle, and its primary function among the given options is depression of the mandible (opening the mouth). "Depression is brought about mainly by the lateral pterygoid" and it is "indispensible for actively opening the mouth."

The lateral pterygoid has the following actions:

  • Depression of the mandible (primary active opener of the mouth)
  • Protrusion of the mandible
  • When one side contracts, it turns the chin to the opposite side

 

While the digastric, geniohyoid, and mylohyoid muscles assist in depression, they primarily help when the mouth is opened wide or against resistance. The lateral pterygoid is the main muscle responsible for actively opening the mouth during normal function.
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Protrusion:

 

  • Protrusion refers to the forward movement of the lower jaw (mandible).
  • The lateral along with medial pterygoid muscle are responsible for protruding the mandible. When this muscle contracts on both sides, it causes the jaw to move forward.

 

Option B. Elevation:

 

  • Elevation refers to the upward movement of the mandible, closing the mouth.
  • The primary muscles responsible for jaw elevation are the masseter, temporalis, and medial pterygoid muscles. The lateral pterygoid's main function is not jaw elevation but rather protrusion.

 

Option D. Retraction:

 

  • Retraction refers to the backward movement of the mandible.
  • The primary muscles involved in jaw retraction are the temporalis and the posterior fibers of the digastric muscle. The lateral pterygoid is not primarily responsible for this movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Which of the marked foramen does the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve pass through? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Explanation

 

The mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve passes through the foramen ovale which is marked as 4 in the above image.

 

The foramen ovale is also located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone.

 

The structure that passes through the foramen ovale is the mandibular nerve (the third division of the trigeminal nerve, Cranial Nerve V3). It carries sensory information from the face and provides motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Foramen ovale is situated anterior and medial to foramen spinosum, and is larger in size than spinosum.


Structures passing vis foramen ovale can be remembered by the following mnemonic
M - Mandibular nerve (3rd division of trigeminal)
A - Accessory meningeal artery
L - Lesser petrosal nerve
E - emissary veins
 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foramen Spinosum:

 

  • The foramen spinosum is a small foramen located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone, near the foramen ovale.
  • The structure that passes through the foramen spinosum is the middle meningeal artery. This artery supplies blood to the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord.

 

Option B. Internal Acoustic Meatus:

 

  • The internal acoustic meatus is located in the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • Several important structures pass through this foramen:
    1. Facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII): It carries motor and sensory fibers related to the muscles of facial expression and taste sensations from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue.
    2. Vestibulocochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve VIII): It carries sensory information related to hearing and balance.

 

Option C. Jugular Foramen:

 

  • The jugular foramen is located at the junction of the temporal and occipital bones, near the base of the skull.
  • Several structures pass through the jugular foramen:
    1. Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX): It carries motor and sensory fibers to the pharynx and taste sensations from the posterior one-third of the tongue.
    2. Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X): It carries motor and sensory fibers to various organs in the thorax and abdomen and plays a crucial role in autonomic functions.
    3. Accessory nerve (Cranial Nerve XI): It supplies motor fibers to the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.
    4. Internal jugular vein: It is a major vein that drains blood from the brain and parts of the face.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secretory vesicles

 

Explanation

 

  • The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph indicates presynaptic secretory vesicles.
  • The structure marked with the arrowhead is postsynaptic density.
  • The secretory vesicles are synthesized by the neurons and are involved in electrochemical signalling in the brain and neuromuscular junctions.
  • In the synaptic region, the plasma membrane of the presynaptic cell is specialized for vesicle exocytosis; synaptic vesicles, which contain a neurotransmitter, are clustered in these regions. The opposing membrane of the postsynaptic cell (in this case, a neuron) contains receptors for the neurotransmitter.

 

 

On electron microscopy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A . Mitochondria appear as round or elliptical bodies of 0.5-2.0 micron long on an electron microscope, consisting of an outer and an inner mitochondrial membrane, cristae, and mitochondrial matrix.

 

 

Option B. Golgi bodies (or Golgi apparatus) appear as stacks of flattened membranous cisternae surrounded by clusters of vesicles.

 

 

Option D. Ribosomes may be attached to the membrane of the rough endoplasmic reticulum (as shown in the image below), or else, they may exist as monosomes or as a chain of granular structures called polyribosomes associated with mRNA

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The structure marked with the asterisk in the electron micrograph represents presynaptic secretory vesicles, essential for neurotransmitter storage and release during synaptic transmission, highlighting their role in neuronal communication.

questions.text: In the image given below, identify the muscle responsible for the opening of the mouth? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. b

 

In the above image the structure marked ‘b’ represents the lateral pterygoid muscle which is responsible for opening the mouth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. a-Temporalis: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and retraction of mandible.

 

Option C. c – Medial pterygoid: This muscle is responsible for Elevation and ‘side-to-side’ movements of the mandible.

 

Option D. d –Buccinator: This muscle is responsible for compresses cheek against molar teeth
 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Muscles of mastication

questions.text: Identify the structure passing through the foramen marked 2? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Abducens nerve

 

The foramen marked as 2 in the given image is the superior orbital fissure and the abducens nerve passes through it.

 

Superior ophthalmic fissure is divided into 3 parts by annulus of zinn, parts of fissure and structures passing via each part are listed below:

  1. Superior -lateral part - Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve, trochlear nerve, superior opthalmic vein, lacrimal artery, meningeal branch of lacrimal artery. (Lacrimal nerve, frontal nerve and trochlear nerve are the branches of ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve.
  2. Middle/ Intermediate part - Nasocillary nerve (branch of ophthalmic division of trigeminal), occulomotor nerve (CN 3), abducens nerve (CN - 6) 
  3. Infero - medial part - Inferior opthalmic vein.


Note - Opthalmic vein passes via superior orbital fissure and not artery. Opthalmic artery passes via optic canal.
 

Brief summary about important structures passing via superior ophthalmic fissure is given below
 

Abducens Nerve (Cranial Nerve VI): The abducens nerve is responsible for controlling the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is essential for eye abduction (outward movement). Damage to the abducens nerve can result in difficulty moving the affected eye outward, leading to diplopia (double vision) when looking toward the affected side.

 

Ophthalmic Division of Trigeminal Nerve (Cranial Nerve V1): The ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve carries sensory information from the upper face, including the forehead, scalp, and anterior part of the scalp. It also provides sensory innervation to the cornea, conjunctiva, and other structures within the orbit.

 

Trochlear Nerve (Cranial Nerve IV): The trochlear nerve controls the superior oblique muscle of the eye, which is responsible for rotating the eye downward and laterally. Damage to the trochlear nerve can lead to difficulty moving the affected eye downward and inward, causing vertical diplopia.

 

Superior ophthalmic vein

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spinal Accessory Nerve: This nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure. It primarily traverses the jugular foramen and is involved in motor functions, particularly in controlling the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

Option C. Ophthalmic Artery: Although the ophthalmic artery passes through the orbit, it is not transmitted through the foramen marked 2 but accompanies the optic nerve through the optic canal.

 

Option D. Middle Meningeal Artery: The middle meningeal artery enters the cranial cavity through the foramen spinosum, not the superior orbital fissure.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ball and socket joint

 

Explanation:

 

The talocalcaneonavicular joint is a ball and socket joint.

 

  • The ball part is formed by the rounded head of the talus.
  • The socket is formed by 3 structures:
    • Posterior surface of the navicular
    • Anterior articular surface of the calcaneus
    • Upper surface of the plantar calcaneo-navicular ligament (spring ligament).

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Saddle Type: A saddle joint, also known as a sellar joint, is a type of synovial joint found in the thumb (between the trapezium bone and the first metacarpal bone). It allows movement in two planes, such as flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. The talocalcaneonavicular joint does not fit this description.

 

Option B. Plane: A plane joint, also called a gliding joint, allows for limited sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. While there are gliding joints in the foot, the talocalcaneonavicular joint is not primarily classified as a plane joint.

 

Option C. Ellipsoid (Condyloid): An ellipsoid joint, also known as a condyloid joint, is a synovial joint that allows movement in two planes: flexion-extension and abduction-adduction. This type of joint has an oval-shaped convex surface fitting into an elliptical concave surface.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ball and socket joint is characterized by a spherical head fitting into a cup-like socket. This type of joint allows for a wide range of motion in multiple planes. The talocalcaneonavicular joint is  a ball and socket joint.

questions.text: Which of the following is connected to the structure marked as A in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Striate cortex

 

Explanation:

 

  • The structure marked A in the above image is the splenium of the corpus callosum and it is connected to the striate cortex.
  • The striate cortex, also known as the primary visual cortex or V1, is involved in early visual processing, such as processing basic features of visual stimuli like edges, orientation, and motion. It does have connections to the splenium of the corpus callosum, especially for the transfer of visual information between the hemispheres. This connection allows the brain to process visual information from both eyes and integrate it into a cohesive visual experience.
  • The splenium of the corpus callosum primarily connects various regions of the cerebral hemispheres, facilitating communication between the left and right cerebral hemispheres.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Orbital Cortex: The orbital cortex is involved in various aspects of emotional processing and decision-making. It is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum.

 

Option B. Hippocampus: The hippocampus is a crucial structure for memory formation and spatial navigation. While it has connections to other parts of the brain, its primary connection to the corpus callosum is through the more anterior parts, not the splenium.

 

Option D. Optic Chiasma: The optic chiasma is not directly connected to the splenium of the corpus callosum. It is a structure located at the base of the brain where some of the optic nerve fibers from each eye cross over to the opposite side of the brain. This crossover allows for the integration of visual input from both eyes, but it occurs before the information reaches the corpus callosum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The corpus callosum is divided into four parts: 
    • The rostrum is continuous with the lamina terminalis and connects the orbital surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The genu is the bend of the anterior corpus callosum and the forceps minor is a tract that projects fibres from the genu to connect the medial and lateral surfaces of the frontal lobes.
    • The body forms the long central section and its fibres pass through the corona radiata to reach the surface of the hemispheres. 
    • The splenium tapers away at the posterior section, with the forceps major projecting fibres from the splenium to connect the two occipital lobes. Striate cortex (visual area) is located in occupital lobe.
  • The hippocampus is not connected directly to the splenium, but situated inferior to the splenium.

questions.text: The structure passing through the central tendon of the diaphragm is: (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Inferior vena cava

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior vena cava is a major vein that returns deoxygenated blood from the lower half of the body to the right atrium of the heart. The IVC passes through the diaphragm via the caval opening, which is situated to the right of the central tendon. This opening allows the IVC to move between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oesophagus: The esophagus passes through an opening in the diaphragm called the esophageal hiatus, which is located just to the left of the central tendon. This allows the esophagus to traverse from the thoracic cavity to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option B. Aorta: The descending (thoracic) aorta carries oxygenated blood from the heart to the lower parts of the body. It passes through the diaphragm via the aortic hiatus, which is posterior to the central tendon. The aorta then continues its descent into the abdominal cavity.

 

Option D. Sympathetic Chain: The sympathetic chain, also known as the sympathetic trunk or sympathetic ganglia, consists of a series of ganglia connected by nerve fibers. It runs vertically along each side of the vertebral column and is not directly associated with the diaphragm or its central tendon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diaphragm has three anatomic openings: the aortic hiatus (T12), the esophageal hiatus (T10), and the caval foramen (T8)

 

  • The inferior vena cava passes through the central tendon of the diaphragm from the caval foramen.
  • Esophagus passes through the esophageal hiatus.
  • Aorta passes through the aortic hiatus.

 

Sympathetic chain passes through the minor apertures crossing the crura of the diaphragm.

questions.text: Shape of Trapezius muscle is? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Triangular

 

Explanation:

 

  • The trapezius muscle is a large, triangular and paired muscle located on the posterior aspect of the neck and thorax. 
  • Each trapezius muscle is flat and triangularly shaped, with the base of the triangle situated along the vertebral column (the muscle's origin) and the apex pointing toward the tip of the shoulder (the muscle's insertion).

 

 

  • Trapezius muscle shape:
    • Considering left or right side - triangular shape
    • Considering both sides together - diamond shaped, hence named "trapezius"

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trapezius muscle:

questions.text: Inferior thyroid artery is the branch of which of the following? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thyrocervical trunk

 

Explanation:

 

The inferior thyroid artery is a branch of the thyrocervical trunk, which is a branch of the subclavian artery's first part. The inferior thyroid artery ascends anterior to the medial border of the scalenus anterior, then turns medially just below the sixth cervical transverse process and descends on longus colli to the thyroid gland's lower border.

 

 

The relationships between the terminal branches and the recurrent laryngeal nerve are highly variable and have significant surgical implications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External Carotid Artery: The external carotid artery supplies most of the structures in the neck, face, scalp, and the upper part of the skull. This artery has several branches, including the superior thyroid, lingual, facial, maxillary, and superficial temporal arteries, among others. While it does supply areas around the thyroid, especially through its superior thyroid branch, it is not the origin of the inferior thyroid artery.

 

Option B. Internal Carotid Artery: The internal carotid artery has no branches in the neck. Instead, it moves upward to supply the brain and eyes. It's essential for cerebral circulation and plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the brain.

 

Option D. Lingual Artery: The lingual artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. It supplies the muscles and mucosa of the tongue. Given its role and location, it is not involved in supplying the thyroid gland or associated structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The thyrocervical trunk is a short branch of the subclavian artery, and it supplies numerous structures in the neck. The branches of the thyrocervical trunk are the inferior thyroid artery, the ascending cervical artery, and the transverse cervical artery (which can further divide into superficial and deep branches). The inferior thyroid artery, which arises from the thyrocervical trunk, mainly supplies the thyroid and parathyroid glands.

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle is absent in which compartment of the leg? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior superficial compartment

 

There is no neurovascular bundle in the leg's posterior superficial compartment.

 

The transverse intermuscular septum divides the posterior compartment of the leg into deep and superficial compartments.

 

The gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soles muscles are found in the posterior superficial compartment.

    

 

Neurovascular components in various compartments of leg are as follows:

 

  • Anterior compartment: Anterior tibial artery and Deep fibular/peroneal nerve
  • Posterior deep compartment: Tibial nerve and posterior tibial vessels in the deep plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment primarily contains the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (fibularis longus and fibularis brevis in newer nomenclature).
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve. The blood supply comes from branches of the anterior tibial and fibular (peroneal) arteries.

 

Option C. Posterior Deep Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment contains the popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. The blood supply primarily comes from the posterior tibial artery.

 

Option D. Anterior Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment houses the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and fibularis (peroneus) tertius.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. The anterior tibial artery supplies blood to this compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Superficial Compartment has the gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris muscles. These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. However, this compartment does not have a specific named artery or vein running through it, as the main vessels (the posterior tibial and fibular arteries and their accompanying veins) are located deep in the leg, closer to the bones. Instead, the vascular supply to these muscles comes from branching vessels that penetrate the compartment.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with inability to form words but can make noises. He also knows what he wants to say. What area of the brain has been damaged in this patient? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Broca's area

 

Broca's area (areas 44, 45) in this patient is damaged. This is located in the posterior part of the frontal lobe, usually in the dominant hemisphere (the left hemisphere in most right-handed individuals).

 

Function: Broca’s area is critical for speech production and grammar processing. Damage to Broca's area results in expressive or non-fluent aphasia. Patients typically understand spoken language and know what they want to say but struggle to form words or construct sentences. Their speech might be slow, with a struggle to find the right words, and they might omit small connecting words like "is" or "the."

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's Area:

 

  • Location: This area is located in the posterior part of the superior temporal gyrus in the dominant cerebral hemisphere, which is the left hemisphere in about 95% of right-handed individuals and 70% of left-handed individuals.
  • Function: Wernicke's area is involved in language comprehension. Damage to this area results in receptive aphasia. Patients can produce speech, but it often lacks meaning, and they have difficulty understanding spoken or written language. Their speech might be fluent, but it's usually nonsensical or includes made-up words.

 

Option C. Heschl's Gyrus:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary auditory cortex within the Sylvian fissure in the temporal lobe.
  • Function: Heschl's gyrus is responsible for primary auditory processing, meaning it processes incoming auditory information. Damage to this area might impair the ability to perceive sounds.

 

Option D. Striate Area:

 

  • Location: Located in the primary visual cortex in the occipital lobe.
  • Function: The striate area (or V1) is the primary processing center for visual information. Damage to this area can lead to blindness or partial visual field deficits depending on the extent and location of the injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Identify the wrongly marked structure in the diagram? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. C-Hypothalamus

 

The image shows the midsagittal section of the brain. The wrongly marked structure is C-hypothalamus. The structure marked as C corresponds to the thalamus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Corpus Callosum: It's a large white matter structure found deep within the brain, lying superiorly to the thalamus and under the cortex. It connects the two cerebral hemispheres.

 

  • The primary purpose of the corpus callosum is to integrate motor, sensory, and cognitive performances between the cerebral cortex on one side of the brain to the same region on the other side. Essentially, it allows for communication between the two hemispheres of the brain.

 

Option C. Pituitary Gland: It is a pea-sized structure that's located at the base of the brain, right below the hypothalamus.

 

  • Often referred to as the "master gland," the pituitary gland secretes hormones that control several other endocrine glands. It has an anterior and posterior portion, each releasing specific hormones. These hormones regulate various physiological processes, including growth, reproductive cycles, and stress response.

 

Option D. Cerebellum: Located at the ventral part of the brain, below the occipital lobes and posterior to the brainstem.

 

  • The cerebellum is primarily responsible for coordination and fine-tuning of motor movements. It also plays roles in posture and balance, and there is increasing evidence that it's involved in cognitive functions and emotion regulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypothalamus is situated at the base of the brain, just below the thalamus and right above the pituitary gland. This plays a crucial role in many important functions, including releasing hormones, regulating body temperature, maintaining daily physiological cycles, controlling appetite, managing of sexual behavior, and responding to the feeling of being full (eating).

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Anterior interosseous nerve

 

Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb, is due to the involvement of the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN). This is a branch of the median nerve. It runs down the forearm along with the anterior interosseous artery.

 

It supplies the deep muscles of the anterior (flexor) compartment of the forearm. Specifically, it provides innervation to the flexor pollicis longus (which flexes the interphalangeal joint of the thumb), the radial half of the flexor digitorum profundus, and the pronator quadratus. Injury to this nerve can lead to the inability to flex the interphalangeal joint of the thumb and the distal phalanges of the index and middle fingers, leading to the characteristic "pinch sign" or "OK sign" presentation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deep Branch of Ulnar Nerve: It arises from the ulnar nerve after it passes the flexor retinaculum in the wrist. The deep branch is mainly motor in function.

 

  • This nerve supplies the hypothenar muscles (muscles of the little finger), the ulnar two lumbricals, all the interossei (both palmar and dorsal), and adductor pollicis. It does not have any role in the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Option B. Median Nerve: This nerve originates from both the medial and lateral cords of the brachial plexus. It travels down the arm and forearm and goes through the carpal tunnel at the wrist.

 

  • It supplies most of the flexors in the forearm and several muscles in the hand, including the thenar muscles (muscles of the thumb). But the flexion at the interphalangeal joint of the thumb is more specifically due to the anterior interosseous branch of the median nerve, not the main trunk of the median nerve.

 

Option C. Posterior Interosseous Nerve: It is a continuation of the deep branch of the radial nerve. It travels in the forearm between the superficial and deep layers of muscles.

 

  • This nerve supplies the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. It's not involved in flexion movements and hence, not responsible for the flexion of the interphalangeal joint of the thumb.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flexion of thumb occurs at 2 joints:

 

  1. IP joint: Flexor pollicis longs (FPL) supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve, C7 and C8).
  2. MCP joint: Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB supplied by the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve.

 

Most commonly injured nerve in SCH fracture: AIN > Median > Radial > Ulnar (AMRU)

 

  • Deep branch of ulnar nerve → ulnar claw hand
  • Posterior interosseous nerve → innervates the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. Weakness or paralysis of these muscles can cause difficulty in extending the wrist and fingers

questions.text: Purkinje cells of cerebellum relay into: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Dentate nucleus

 

Explanation:

 

The cerebellum's purkinje cells relay information to the dentate nucleus, one of the deep cerebellar nuclei.

 

It is the cerebellum's distinguishing cell. It is a large flask-shaped cell. Climbing fibres from the inferior olivary nucleus stimulate it. This cell's main output is inhibitory in nature and is directed at cerebellar nuclei. These are the most important output neurons.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caudate Nucleus: It's one of the structures that make up the basal ganglia in the brain. The caudate nucleus has a long, C-shaped structure and is located laterally in the brain, near the lateral ventricles. It plays roles in various functions like voluntary movement control, learning, memory, and emotion. Purkinje cells do not primarily relay into the caudate nucleus.

 

Option B. Lentiform Nucleus: Another component of the basal ganglia, the lentiform nucleus is located deep within the brain and is laterally placed in relation to the thalamus. The lentiform nucleus is made up of two structures: the putamen and the globus pallidus. It's involved in movement regulation and other functions. Purkinje cells do not have a direct relay into the lentiform nucleus.

 

Option D. Red Nucleus: Found in the midbrain, the red nucleus has a reddish hue due to its rich blood supply and the presence of iron. It plays a role in motor coordination, particularly in the coordination of limb movements. While the red nucleus does receive input from the cerebellum, the primary relay from Purkinje cells is to the deep cerebellar nuclei, not directly to the red nucleus. The dentate nucleus, in turn, can send projections to the red nucleus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dentate Nucleus is one of the deep cerebellar nuclei and is situated within the white matter of the cerebellum. The dentate nucleus is the largest of the deep cerebellar nuclei and plays a role in the planning, initiation, and control of voluntary movements.

 

Purkinje cells in the cerebellar cortex send inhibitory projections to the deep cerebellar nuclei, including the dentate nucleus. This is the main output pathway for the cerebellar cortex.

questions.text: Which of the following sensations is not perceived by the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Proprioception

 

Explanation:

 

Proprioception refers to the sense of the relative position of body parts and the strength of effort being employed in movement. It provides the brain with information about limb position, movement, and force. It is perceived by the mesencephalic nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Temperature: Temperature sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive differences in external and internal temperatures.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve plays a key role in mediating temperature sensations from the face. It receives input from the descending or spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve for temperature sensation from the face.

 

Option B. Pain: Pain is an unpleasant sensory and emotional experience associated with actual or potential tissue damage.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: The spinal nucleus is responsible for pain sensation from the face. Pain fibers from the face descend along the spinal tract of the trigeminal nerve and synapse in the spinal nucleus of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Option C. Touch: Touch or tactile sensation refers to the ability of the body to perceive pressure or contact with the skin.

 

  • Relation to Spinal Nucleus of Trigeminal Nerve: Light touch from the face is also processed by the spinal nucleus, but it's worth noting that discriminative touch (ability to recognize specific shapes and textures) from the face is primarily processed by the main or chief sensory nucleus of the trigeminal nerve, not the spinal nucleus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The trigeminal nerve consists of 4 nuclei:

questions.text: The structure marked with the black arrow in the given picture arises from the ……… (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hippocampus

 

Explanation:

 

This is a coronal section of the brain and the marked structure is the fornix. It arises from the hippocampus and ends in the mammillary body of the hypothalamus.

 

Hippocampus is located in the medial temporal lobe of the brain.

 

The hippocampus is critical for the formation and retrieval of memories, particularly episodic memories. It's also involved in spatial navigation. Damage or atrophy of the hippocampus can result in difficulties forming new memories. Conditions like Alzheimer's disease often exhibit significant hippocampal atrophy.


Other Options:

 

Option A. Mamillary body: Part of the diencephalon, present at the base of the brain, posterior to the pituitary gland.

 

  • The mammillary bodies are primarily associated with memory processing. They receive projections from the hippocampus via the fornix and send projections to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. They're particularly involved in the recall of past memories and are thought to play a role in spatial memory. Damage to the mammillary bodies, often due to thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency as seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, can lead to memory deficits.

 

Option C. Thalamus: Positioned centrally in the brain, the thalamus is a large mass of gray matter deep within the brain. It is part of the diencephalon.

 

  • Often referred to as the "relay station" of the brain, the thalamus receives sensory and motor signals and relays them to the cerebral cortex. It's involved in consciousness, sleep, and alertness. Thalamic strokes or lesions can lead to sensory deficits, altered consciousness, and movement disorders.

 

Option D. Amygdala: Located in the anterior portion of the temporal lobe, deep within the brain.

 

  • The amygdala plays a pivotal role in processing emotions, particularly fear and pleasure. It helps determine which memories are stored and where they are stored based on emotional significance. Dysfunction of the amygdala can lead to various emotional and behavioral abnormalities. It's also implicated in conditions such as anxiety disorders and post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronal Section of Brain

choices.text: Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa
Accessory meningeal branch of maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa
Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa

questions.text: Which of the following arteries does not supply the corresponding region of the dura mater? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Meningeal branch of internal carotid artery - Posterior cranial fossa

 

Explanation:

 

  • This is the incorrect pairing. The meningeal branch of the internal carotid artery doesn't primarily supply the dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa. The dura mater of the posterior cranial fossa is mainly supplied by branches from the vertebral arteries, such as the posterior meningeal artery.
  • The meningeal branches of Internal Carotid artery supply the anterior cranial fossa 
     

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Middle meningeal artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The middle meningeal artery is a branch of the maxillary artery. It is the most significant arterial supply to the dura mater. After entering the skull through the foramen spinosum, it typically divides into anterior and posterior branches. The anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies the dura mater overlying the anterior cranial fossa.

 

Option B. Accessory meningeal branch of the maxillary artery - Middle cranial fossa: The accessory meningeal artery is a smaller branch that originates from the maxillary artery. It enters the middle cranial fossa through the foramen ovale. This artery supplies the dura of the middle cranial fossa.

 

Option D. Meningeal branch of anterior and posterior ethmoid artery - Anterior cranial fossa: The anterior and posterior ethmoidal arteries arise from the ophthalmic artery (a branch of the internal carotid artery). These arteries have meningeal branches that supply the dura mater in the anterior cranial fossa, specifically the region overlying the ethmoid bone and the frontal bone's adjacent parts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Summary of Blood supply to Dura

  1. Anterior cranial fossa
    1. By ethmoidal artery which is the branch of opthalmic artery which in tern is the branch of Internal carotid artery 
    2. Middle meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  2. Middle cranial fossa
    1. Accessory meningeal artery which is the branch of maxillary artery which in tern is the branch of external carotid artery
  3. Posterior Cranial fossa
    1. Meningeal branches from the branches of the vertebral artery.
       
  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) meningeal branch supply blood to the anterior cranial fossa.
  • The dura mater is supplied by meningeal arteries, which run along the inner periosteum (endosteum) of the skull and supply the following regions.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

 

Explanation:

 

The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint.  .

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.

 

Option B. Triquetrum: The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.

 

Option C. Distal end of radius: The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:

 

  • Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum

 

Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

questions.text: The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for which of the following structures:(AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Right atrium

 

Explanation:

 

The region marked corresponds to the surface marking for the right atrium.

 

This image shows the mid-clavicular line, xiphoid process, and costal margin.

 

The examiner marks a laterally convex line that runs from the third costal cartilage, which is located about three spaces below the second costal cartilage (as shown by the sternal angle), to the sixth costal cartilage. The distance between this line and the sternal margin is around 1.2 cm. This imply that the area designated matches the right atrium's surface marking.

 

An average adult's projected cardiac borders onto the front chest wall form a trapezium shape. The percussion approach can be used to map this out by checking for cardiac dullness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thoracic duct: The thoracic duct typically ascends in the posterior mediastinum and does not correspond to the surface marking in the image which is more anterior and lateral.

 

Option C. Inferomedial bronchopulmonary segments: These segments are located more inferiorly in the lung fields and do not correspond to the area marked which is on the chest wall at the level of the heart.

 

Option D. Hilum: The hilum of the lung, where structures enter and exit the lung, is located more laterally than the area marked. It does not align with the vertical placement of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The varying heart borders and the corresponding surface markings are as follows:

 

  • ﻿﻿Upper border: Slopes gently from the second left costal cartilage to the third right costal cartilage. It corresponds to the left atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Right border: Convex to the right and runs from the third to the sixth right costal cartilages, 1-2 cm lateral to the sternal edge. It corresponds to the right atrium.
  • ﻿﻿Inferior border or acute border: Runs leftwards from the 6th right costal cartilage to the cardiac apex which is located approximately
  • 9 cm lateral to the midline, often in the left 5th intercostal space or level with the 5th or 6th rib. It corresponds to the right ventricle.
  • ﻿﻿Left border or obtuse border: Convex laterally on the left. It extends superomedially from the cardiac apex to meet the second left costal cartilage about 1 cm from the left sternal edge. It corresponds to the left ventricle.

questions.text: The action of the muscle attached to the marked area? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Abduction

 

Explanation:

 

The greater trochanter is visible in the photograph, and the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus muscle fibres attach (insert) here. Action of these fibres of abducting the leg, and their anterior fibres rotate the thigh medially.

 

Both are innervated by the superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

 

Hip abduction involves moving the thigh laterally, away from the midline. This is the primary function of both the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus. When you stand on one leg, these muscles contract on the standing side to prevent the pelvis from tilting down on the free side. This stabilizing action is crucial for bipedal walking.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexion: Hip flexion primarily involves lifting the thigh forward in an anterior direction. While the gluteus medius and gluteus minimus can assist in flexion when the hip is initially in extension, this is not their primary function. Main hip flexors include the iliopsoas, rectus femoris, and sartorius.

 

Option B. Adduction: Hip adduction is the action of moving the thigh medially, towards the midline. Gluteus medius and gluteus minimus are not adductors; in fact, they act in opposition to this movement. The primary hip adductors include muscles like the adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus, gracilis, and pectineus.

 

Option D. Extension: Hip extension involves moving the thigh posteriorly. The primary hip extensor is the gluteus maximus, which is the largest of the gluteal muscles. While the gluteus medius and minimus can assist in hip extension when the hip is initially flexed, this is not their main action.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following finger has two dorsal interossei muscles? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle finger

 

Explanation:

 

The middle finger has two dorsal interossei muscles flanking it. One is positioned between the index and middle fingers, and the other is positioned between the middle and ring fingers.

 

This anatomical configuration allows the middle finger to be abducted in both directions: towards the index finger and towards the ring finger.

 

 

The dorsal interossei muscles are four bipennate muscles located between the metacarpal bones in the hand. They are named "dorsal" because they are located on the dorsum (back) of the hand, and "interossei" means between bones. Their main action is to abduct the fingers away from the axial line, which runs down the center of the third (middle) finger.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Index finger: This finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts the index finger away from the middle finger.

 

Option B. Little finger: The little finger also has one dorsal interosseous muscle. This muscle abducts the little finger away from the ring finger.

 

Option D. Ring finger: The ring finger has one dorsal interosseous muscle which abducts it away from the little finger.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Portal vein

 

The structure that divides the liver in Couinaud's classification system is the portal vein.

 

The portal vein is a significant vessel that delivers blood from the gastrointestinal tract, spleen, pancreas, and gallbladder to the liver.

 

In the context of Couinaud's classification, the liver is divided into right and left lobes by the main portal vein. Further segmentation divides each lobe into individual segments based on the branches of the portal vein. As such, the portal vein is the primary structure used in Couinaud's system to determine liver segmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery provides oxygen-rich blood to the liver. While it is part of the portal triad and serves individual liver segments, it is not the primary structure used to define the segments in Couinaud's classification. The segmentation is based on the portal vein's distribution, although the hepatic artery's branches supply the respective segments concurrently.

 

Option C. Bile duct: The bile ducts are responsible for transporting bile produced in the liver to the gallbladder for storage or directly to the small intestine for digestion. Similar to the hepatic artery, while bile ducts are part of the portal triad and serve individual liver segments, they aren't the primary structure used for segmentation in the Couinaud's system.

 

Option D. Cystic duct: The cystic duct connects the gallbladder to the common bile duct. It does not have a direct role in dividing the liver into its segments and is unrelated to Couinaud's classification system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Illustration of the segmental anatomy of the liver based on the third-order portal vein branching (Couinaud's classification system) and the portal vein and hepatic vein branches.

 

IVC: inferior vena cava and PV: portal vein.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle is not supplied by the structure marked by red arrow? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Superior oblique

 

The superior oblique muscle is not supplied by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure highlighted in the figure. Superior oblique muscle is supplied by the trochlear nerve.

 

All the extraocular muscles are innervated by the oculomotor (III) nerve except:

 

  • ﻿﻿Lateral rectus which is supplied by abducens (VI) nerve
  • ﻿﻿Superior oblique which is supplied by trochlear (IV) nerve

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior rectus: This muscle is innervated by the oculomotor nerve, which is the structure indicated by the red arrow in the image. This muscle helps in elevating the eye.

 

Option C. Medial rectus: Also supplied by the oculomotor nerve, this muscle is responsible for adducting the eye towards the nose.

 

Option D. Levator palpebrae superioris (LPS): Innervated by the oculomotor nerve, the LPS is essential for elevating the upper eyelid, enabling the opening of the eye.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: The wrong statement regarding the levator ani muscle is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Attached to pelvic brim

 

Explanation:

 

The levator ani is not attached to the pelvic brim. Instead, it originates from the posterior surface of the body of the pubis, the obturator fascia, and the ischial spine. It then inserts into the coccyx, anococcygeal ligament, and walls of the prostate or vagina, rectum, and anal canal. The incorrect notion about its attachment to the pelvic brim is a common misconception.

 

  • Insertion :- The coccyx and the anococcygeal raphe or ligament.
  • Nerve supply:- The branches of the anterior rami of sacral nerves S3 and S4 and the perineal branch of the pudendal nerve.
  • Supports and raises the pelvic floor.
  •  Consists of the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supports pelvic viscera: This statement is correct. The levator ani, along with other pelvic floor muscles, forms a supportive sling for the pelvic organs such as the bladder, uterus (in females), and rectum. This muscular support is essential for maintaining continence and facilitating functions such as micturition and defecation.

 

Option B. Converge downwards and medially: This statement is also correct. The fibers of the levator ani muscles, especially from the pubococcygeus, tend to converge towards the midline and run in a downward direction. This orientation provides the necessary support to the pelvic organs and creates a muscular barrier between the pelvic cavity and the perineum.

 

Option C. Consists of iliococcygeus and pubococcygeus: This statement is partially true. The levator ani is made up of three parts: the puborectalis, pubococcygeus, and iliococcygeus. All three parts contribute to the function and support provided by the levator ani. Thus, while the statement includes two components of the levator ani, it omits the puborectalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pelvic brim is not connected to the levator ani muscle. It originates from the ischial spine, levator ani's arcus tendinous (a thickened section of the obturator fascia, and the pubic body.

questions.text:
In the given section of the heart, match the marked (4, 9, 12, 1) structures:

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)
  2. Mitral valve
  3. Tricuspid valve
  4. Papillary muscles
questions.solution:
Ans. C. a-1, b-4, c-9, D-12

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a cut and reflected section of the heart.

 

The ventricles can be identified based upon the wall thickness - Left ventricle has thicker walls.

 

  1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (marked as 1): This structure represents the exit point for blood traveling to the lungs for oxygenation.
  2. Mitral valve (marked as 4): Located between the left atrium and the left ventricle, the mitral valve regulates blood flow within the heart.
  3. Tricuspid valve (marked as 9): This valve, situated between the right atrium and right ventricle, prevents backflow of blood from the ventricles to the atria.
  4. Papillary muscles (marked as 12): These muscles are attached to the ventricular walls and play a critical role in the function of the mitral and tricuspid valves via tendon-like chords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct match is:

 

1. Outflow to pulmonary trunk (blue)

2. Left atrium

3. Pulmonary veins (light red)

4. Mitral valve

5. Aorta (red).

6. Superior vena cava (blue)

7. Aortic semi lunar valve

8. Right atrium

9. Tricuspid valve

10. Right ventricle

11. Inferior vena cave (blue)

12. Papillary muscles

13. Left ventricle

questions.text: A lesion of the structure marked in the image below cause?(AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Contralateral hemiplegia

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the pyramid containing the pyramidal tracts. A lesion here leads to contralateral hemiplegia.

 

This is because the fibers of these tracts decussate (cross over) in the medulla oblongata. Thus, an injury to the pyramidal tract on one side of the brain or upper spinal cord will affect motor function on the opposite side of the body.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ataxia: Ataxia refers to uncoordinated movement and is typically related to damage to the cerebellum or sensory pathways, not the pyramidal tracts. The cerebellum plays a crucial role in fine-tuning motor movements and ensuring coordination. So, an injury to the pyramidal tracts does not typically result in ataxia.

 

Option C. Tinnitus: Tinnitus is the perception of noise or ringing in the ears. It's a symptom of an underlying condition, such as age-related hearing loss, ear injury, or a circulatory system disorder. Injury to the pyramidal tracts would not lead to tinnitus, as they are primarily motor tracts and not involved in auditory processing or function.

 

Option D. Ipsilateral facial palsy: Facial palsy refers to weakness or paralysis of the muscles on one side of the face. It is most commonly associated with damage to the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). While the pyramidal tracts do play a role in voluntary facial movements, a direct injury to these tracts would not typically lead to ipsilateral facial palsy. Furthermore, facial movements are controlled by both sides of the brain, so an isolated pyramidal tract lesion might not manifest as overt facial weakness.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pyramids in the medulla oblongata, containing the pyramidal tracts, are crucial for voluntary motor control. A lesion here can lead to contralateral hemiplegia due to the crossing over of these tracts within the medulla. This understanding is essential for diagnosing and understanding the implications of brainstem injuries, especially in the context of stroke or other neurological disorders.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked a in the image given below? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ulnar artery

 

 

The structure marked in the image is the ulnar artery, seen contributing to the superficial palmar arch.

 

It is a major blood vessel of the forearm that passes alongside the ulna bone. It is essential for supplying blood to the deep and superficial structures of the forearm and hand. In the wrist, the ulnar artery passes through Guyon's canal before contributing to both the superficial and deep palmar arches.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve: Incorrect because the ulnar nerve, while it travels a similar path as the ulnar artery in the forearm, is not a blood vessel but a nerve. It primarily provides sensory and motor innervation to the hand, not blood supply.

 

Option C. Superficial radial artery: Incorrect as this artery travels along the radial side of the forearm and would not be located where the marked structure is. The superficial radial artery is much smaller and does not contribute significantly to the palmar arches.

 

Option D. Median nerve: Incorrect because, like the ulnar nerve, the median nerve is a neural structure responsible for sensory and motor functions in the forearm and hand, not a vascular structure. It travels down the middle of the forearm and does not supply blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ulnar artery is an essential vascular structure for the blood supply to the forearm and hand, particularly contributing to the formation of the palmar arches, which are critical for hand perfusion. Its course alongside the ulna bone and through Guyon's canal makes it a significant artery in the vascular anatomy of the forearm and hand. It passes deep to the Guyon's canal in the wrist and contributes to the superficial and deep palmar arch.

questions.text: True regarding the lesion of the structure marked by 5 the arrow is: (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Wrist drop

 

Explanation:

 

The structure marked in the image is the radial nerve demonstrated in the cubital fossa. A lesion of the radial nerve leads to a wrist drop. Injury to the radial nerve leads to paralysis of the extensor muscles of the wrist and fingers. This results in an inability to extend the wrist and fingers actively, leading to the characteristic "wrist drop" appearance. The hand hangs flaccidly with the fingers flexed, and the person cannot extend them

 

 

Anterior view of the right cubital fossa:

 

The structures marked in the given image are:

 

  1. Branch of the median nerve to the brachialis muscle
  2. Biceps brachii muscle
  3. Brachialis muscle
  4. Lateral cutaneous nerve of fore arm
  5. Superficial branch of the radial nerve
  6. Brachioradialis muscle
  7. Flexor carpi ulnaris muscle
  8. Pronator teres muscle
  9. Brachial artery
  10. Medial cutaneous nerve of forearm
  11. Median nerve.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ape thumb deformity: This deformity is primarily associated with the median nerve lesion. It refers to an inability to oppose or flex the thumb due to weakness or paralysis of the thenar muscles (especially the opponens pollicis), which are innervated by the median nerve. This results in a flattened thenar eminence, giving the thumb an appearance reminiscent of an ape's thumb.

 

Option B. Claw hand: Claw hand, or "clawing" of the fingers, usually results from a combined ulnar and median nerve lesion. It is characterized by hyperextension at the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joints. It can also result from a high ulnar nerve lesion on its own. The claw hand deformity is not a typical consequence of radial nerve injury.

 

Option C. Claudication: Claudication refers to pain, cramping, or fatigue in muscles, typically the calves, during walking or exercise. It's a symptom of peripheral arterial disease, where there's reduced blood flow to the legs. This is not related to radial nerve injury.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Given is a model of embryological development of the heart. Which structure develops from the area marked with red arrow?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Infundibulum

 

Explanation:

 

The marked object is the conus cordis (middle part of bulbus cordis). From this structure, the heart's infundibulum emerges.

 

The heart is represented in the model at the stage of embryology where both heart tubes have merged and are undergoing dextro-looping, or bending. During day 23 of intrauterine life, this occurs.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atria: The atria of the heart primarily develop from the primitive atrial chamber or sinus venosus, not from the conus cordis. The sinus venosus will contribute to the formation of the smooth parts of the right and left atria. The atrial appendages or auricles, however, develop from the primitive atrium.

 

Option B. Left Ventricle: The left ventricle arises mainly from the primitive ventricle of the embryonic heart tube. As the heart develops, the primitive ventricle gives rise to the muscular parts of both the left and right ventricles, but primarily the left.

 

Option D. Interventricular septum:The interventricular septum separates the right and left ventricles. It has a muscular part and a membranous part. The muscular part primarily develops from the growth of the myocardium of the primitive ventricle. The conus cordis and the truncus arteriosus contribute to the formation of the membranous part of the interventricular septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The infundibulum, also referred as the conus arteriosus or the outflow tract, develops from the conus cordis. It represents the smooth-walled, anterior portion of the right ventricle and leads to the pulmonary trunk in the mature heart.

questions.text: A muscle is attached to the area marked in the given image. What is the action of this muscle on the hip joint?(AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Extension and lateral rotation

 

Explanation:

 

The gluteal tuberosity is indicated by the marked area in the photograph. The gluteus maximus, which is implanted here, produces lateral rotation and extension of the hip joint. Extension involves increasing the angle between the femur and the pelvis, essentially the opposite of flexion. Lateral rotation, refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.

 

Three-quarters of the gluteus maximus attach to the iliotibial tract, while one-fourth attach to the gluteal tuberosity (marked in image). The inferior gluteal nerve supplies it. At the hip joint, it serves as the primary extensor of the lower limb. Abduction and lateral rotation are additional effects.

 

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Flexion and medial rotation:

 

  • Flexion is the movement of bending the joint, resulting in a decrease of the angle between the femur and the pelvis. Medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards, toward the midline.
  • The gluteus maximus is not primarily responsible for these actions. Instead, other muscles, such as the iliopsoas and anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, play roles in hip flexion and medial rotation.

 

Option B. Adduction and lateral rotation:

 

  • Adduction involves drawing the limb toward the midline of the body, while lateral rotation refers to turning the anterior aspect of the femur away from the midline.
  • While the gluteus maximus does have fibers that can contribute to lateral rotation, it's not a primary adductor of the hip. Instead, the hip adductors (like adductor longus, adductor brevis, adductor magnus) primarily mediate adduction

 

Option C. Abduction and medial rotation:

 

  • Abduction involves moving the limb away from the midline, and as mentioned above, medial rotation involves turning the anterior aspect of the femur inwards.
  • The gluteus maximus is not a primary abductor or medial rotator of the hip. The gluteus medius and minimus are the primary muscles responsible for hip abduction, and various other muscles, including anterior fibers of the gluteus medius and minimus, contribute to medial rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gluteus maximus is a primary extensor and lateral rotator of the hip joint. When you stand up from a seated position, climb stairs, or rise from a squat, the gluteus maximus is heavily involved in extending the hip.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the area marked A in the given image is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dopamine

 

Explanation:

 

The substantia nigra is the region highlighted in the illustration (meaning- dark substance). Dopamine is the neurotransmitter released by this region.

 

A component of the nigrostriatal pathway is the substantia nigra. Parkinson's disease may be caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine (ACh):

 

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS).
  • In the PNS, ACh is the neurotransmitter released from the axon terminals of motor neurons, making muscles contract. It's also the neurotransmitter in all autonomic ganglia.
  • In the CNS, ACh is involved in a variety of functions, such as attention, arousal, and memory. Loss of cholinergic neurons in the brain, especially in the basal nucleus of Meynert, has been linked with Alzheimer's disease.
  • However, ACh is not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Glutamine:

 

  • It's worth noting that there's a potential mix-up in the options: Glutamine is an amino acid, while "glutamate" is the neurotransmitter.
  • Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS and plays crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, which is the cellular basis for learning and memory.
  • While glutamate is widespread in the brain, it's not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Noradrenaline :

 

  • Noradrenaline is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter. It plays roles in attention, focus, and the fight-or-flight response by preparing the body to react to threats.
  • In the CNS, noradrenergic neurons primarily arise from the locus coeruleus in the pons and project to various regions of the brain, influencing attention, arousal, and mood.
  • While noradrenaline plays a role in various brain functions, it's not the neurotransmitter secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine:

 

Dopamine is one of the major neurotransmitters in the brain and is involved in several key functions, including mood regulation, reward-seeking behavior, and motor control.

 

The substantia nigra, specifically its pars compacta region, contains dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). This pathway is known as the nigrostriatal pathway and is critical for regulating voluntary movement.

 

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is the primary pathological feature of Parkinson's disease, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.

questions.text: Which of the following arteries passes in close proximity to the area marked by the arrow in the given image? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Middle meningeal artery

 

Explanation:

 

The middle meningeal artery (MMA) is a branch of the maxillary artery (a terminal branch of the external carotid artery). The MMA enters the middle cranial fossa by passing through the foramen spinosum. After entering the skull, it courses laterally to the pterion.

 

Given the proximity of the MMA to the pterion, trauma to this region can lead to an extradural (epidural) hematoma if the MMA is torn. This is because the MMA runs just deep to the pterion, between the skull and the dura mater.

 

This makes the MMA the artery most closely related to the pterion, and a fracture at the pterion can lead to rupture of this artery.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Internal carotid artery:

 

  • The internal carotid artery (ICA) is a major artery that supplies blood to the brain. It arises from the common carotid artery and enters the cranial cavity through the carotid canal.
  • While the ICA does travel inside the skull and provides blood to the brain, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion. It is more medial in its course.

 

Option C. Anterior cerebral artery:

 

  • The anterior cerebral artery is one of the terminal branches of the internal carotid artery. It supplies the medial and superior parts of the brain.
  • Though it's an essential artery for cerebral circulation, it doesn't have a direct relationship with the pterion, as its course and distribution are more medial.

 

Option D. Deep temporal artery:

 

  • The deep temporal arteries are branches of the maxillary artery that ascend between the temporalis muscle and the side of the skull.
  • They supply the temporalis muscle, and while they are in the vicinity of the pterion, they are not as closely related as the middle meningeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The pterion is an H shaped sutural junction between four bones of the skull:

 

  • Frontal bone
  • Squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Greater wing of the sphenoid bone
  • Parietal bone.

 

Given that it rests across the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere, it is a significant structure. Since the bone in this region is fragile, any injury could cause the middle meningeal artery to burst, resulting in an extradural hematoma.

questions.text: Where are the Ito cells in the liver located? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Space of disse

 

In the Disse space are Ito cells/Hepatic stellate cells. Their origins are mesenchymal.

 

Between the liver sinusoid and the hepatocytes is a region known as the space of Disse, sometimes known as the perisinusoidal space.

 

Significance of Ito cells:

 

Most of the time, ito cells (also known as stellate cells) are dormant. They are a substantial source of growth factors essential for liver homeostasis and regeneration and store the fat-soluble vitamin A in their lipid droplets.

 

Ito cells become active when there is liver damage. They release intralobular matrix components such collagen type III (reticular) fibres and replace injured hepatocytes with collagenous scar tissue. This leads to hepatic fibrosis.

 

Note: A narrow space which separates limiting plate (a sleeve of modified hepatocytes) from the connective tissue of the portal area is known as space of moll.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Space of Moll:

 

  • The Space of Moll is located in the eyelid and is not related to the liver. Specifically, it refers to a part of the eyelid's lymphatic drainage system.
  • It has no relevance to the location of Ito cells.

 

Option C. Sinusoids:

 

  • Sinusoids are the capillary-like vessels in the liver where the exchange of substances occurs between the blood and hepatocytes.
  • While Ito cells are closely related to sinusoids and are found in the perisinusoidal space, they are not located within the sinusoids themselves.

 

Option D. Bile Canaliculi:

 

  • Bile canaliculi are small ducts between hepatocytes that collect bile produced by the hepatocytes.
  • Ito cells are not located in the bile canaliculi. Instead, these canaliculi are lined by hepatocytes that actively secrete bile into them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Space of Disse (perisinusoidal space) is a small space between the sinusoidal endothelial cells and the hepatocytes. Ito cells are located in this space. When there is liver injury, these cells can become activated, transform into myofibroblast-like cells, and contribute to the production of collagen and extracellular matrix, leading to liver fibrosis.

choices.text: Basal lamina lining the serous acini
Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip

questions.text: Which of the following features differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absence of striated duct

 

Absence of striated duct in exocrine pancreas differentiates it from the parotid gland.

 

The exocrine pancreas is comprised entirely of serous acini. Therefore, its general structure is similar to that of the parotid gland, but the two are easily distinguished by:

 

  1. The parotid gland has striated and intercalated intralobular ducts, whereas the pancreas has only the intercalated type.
  2. The excretory ducts of the parotid gland are striated columnar, whereas the excretory duct of the pancreas is a simple columnar.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Basal lamina lining the serous acini: Both exocrine pancreas and parotid gland have serous acini that are lined by a basal lamina. Basal lamina is a thin extracellular matrix layer that underlies epithelial tissues and surrounds the cells in muscles, fat, and Schwann cells. So, this feature does not differentiate the two.

 

Option C. Presence of serous acini with acidophilic tip: Both the exocrine pancreas and the parotid gland have serous acini. In the pancreas, these acinar cells have an acidophilic (eosinophilic) cytoplasm because they contain zymogen granules, which are precursors of digestive enzymes. The parotid gland is purely serous, and its acinar cells also have zymogen granules. Thus, this feature does not uniquely differentiate the two glands.

 

Option D. Presence of apical acinar villi: While the exocrine pancreas has acinar cells with a fine, microvillous border at the apical side (facing the lumen) to increase the secretory surface, this is not a feature that starkly contrasts with the parotid gland. Acinar cells in the parotid gland also have secretory granules toward their apical side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Striated ducts are a characteristic feature of salivary glands, including the parotid gland. These ducts have basal infoldings associated with mitochondria, which gives them their "striated" appearance. They play a role in modifying the primary saliva produced by the acinar cells. The exocrine pancreas does not possess striated ducts. Instead, it has intercalated ducts that connect the acinar cells to the larger duct system. This feature, therefore, differentiates the exocrine pancreas from the parotid gland.

questions.text: Medial lemniscus is a continuation of which of the following structures? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fasciculus gracilis

 

Medial lemniscus is a continuation of fasciculus gracilis as well as fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Posterior column-medial lemniscal pathway:

 

In the dorsal horn, first-order axons carrying proprioception vibration  and two point discrimination sensations continue their upward journey as the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus.

 

Fibers of these fasciculi synapse on the second-order neurons of the ipsilateral nuclei gracilis and cuneatus in the medulla oblongata, respectively.

 

Axons of these second-order neurons then cross over as the internal arcuate fibers to form the medial lemniscus in the contralateral medulla.

 

These second-order axons ascend through the brainstem to reach the third-order neuronal cell bodies in the ventral posterior lateral nucleus of the thalamus. Axons from the third-order neurons then project through the posterior limb of the internal capsule to reach the primary somatosensory cortex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spinothalamic tract: The spinothalamic tract is an important ascending pathway that primarily carries pain, temperature, and crude touch sensations. The pathway originates from the spinal cord and projects directly to the thalamus without becoming the medial lemniscus. However, after relaying in the thalamus, fibers from the spinothalamic tract and the medial lemniscus converge to project to similar regions of the cerebral cortex.

 

Option B. Spinocerebellar tract: The spinocerebellar tracts (anterior and posterior) are pathways that convey proprioceptive information (concerning the position and movement of body parts) from the body to the cerebellum. They do not form the medial lemniscus.

 

Option C. Spinotectal tract: The spinotectal tract is an ascending pathway that carries sensory information related to reflex movements of the eyes and head in response to visual and tactile stimuli. It connects the spinal cord to the tectum of the midbrain (specifically, the superior colliculus). It does not become the medial lemniscus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fasciculus gracilis (and its counterpart, the fasciculus cuneatus) are ascending tracts in the spinal cord that carry fine touch, vibration, and proprioceptive sensations from the body to the brain.

 

These fibers travel upwards in the spinal cord and synapse in the nucleus gracilis (and nucleus cuneatus for the fasciculus cuneatus) located in the medulla oblongata. After synapsing, second-order neurons cross the midline and form the medial lemniscus, which then ascends to the thalamus.

 

Thus, the medial lemniscus is indeed a continuation of the fibers originally present in the fasciculus gracilis (and fasciculus cuneatus).

questions.text: The type of fibers present in the fornix are? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Association and commisural fibers
